title: Functional Cognitive Disorder (FCD)
icd10: R41.89 (Other symptoms and signs involving cognitive functions and awareness)
scope: ** Evaluation and management of functional cognitive disorder -- subjective cognitive complaints (memory, attention, word-finding, concentration) with normal or near-normal objective neuropsychological testing. Differentiation from neurodegenerative dementias (Alzheimer disease, frontotemporal dementia, Lewy body dementia), mild cognitive impairment (MCI), and other organic causes of cognitive decline. Cognitive behavioral approaches, psychoeducation, and management of perpetuating comorbidities (depression, anxiety, sleep disorders, chronic pain). Complements existing FND and Dementia Evaluation plans. For broader FND management, see "Functional Neurological Disorder" template. For neurodegenerative dementia workup, see "Dementia Evaluation" template.

Essential/Core Labs.rationale: Baseline; rule out anemia, infection as contributor to cognitive symptoms
Metabolic encephalopathy screen; hepatic/renal dysfunction causing cognitive impairment
Hypothyroidism is a common, reversible cause of cognitive complaints
B12 deficiency causes reversible cognitive impairment and must be excluded
Folate deficiency associated with cognitive impairment
Hypoglycemia/hyperglycemia as contributor to cognitive symptoms
Deficiency associated with cognitive complaints, fatigue, and mood disorders

Extended Workup (Context-Dependent).rationale: Neurosyphilis screen if risk factors or atypical presentation
HIV-associated neurocognitive disorder in at-risk populations
Chronic glucose dysregulation contributing to cognitive symptoms
UTI as contributor to acute cognitive change (especially elderly)
Substance use contributing to cognitive complaints
Hashimoto encephalopathy if autoimmune features present
Functional B12 deficiency when serum B12 borderline (200-400 pg/mL)
Adrenal insufficiency causing fatigue and cognitive symptoms

Rare/Specialized.item: Autoimmune encephalitis antibody panel (serum and CSF)
Rare/Specialized.rationale: If subacute onset cognitive decline with psychiatric features; rule out anti-NMDAR or anti-LGI1 encephalitis
If atypical features, cancer history, or rapidly progressive cognitive decline
If endemic area with compatible history
If genuine concern for early Alzheimer disease vs FCD -- normal biomarkers strongly support FCD

Essential/First-line.item: MRI brain with and without contrast (CPT 70553)
Essential/First-line.timing: Within 2-4 weeks; not urgent unless red flags
Essential/First-line.target: Normal (no atrophy, no white matter disease, no mass); provides reassurance and excludes structural pathology
Normal or near-normal performance with internal inconsistency; effort testing normal; pattern inconsistent with neurodegenerative profile (see Clinical Notes)

Extended.target: Score typically normal (>26/30 MoCA) or mildly reduced due to inattention; stability over time supports FCD

Extended.timing: If clinical uncertainty between FCD and early neurodegeneration
Extended.target: Normal metabolism (no temporoparietal or frontal hypometabolism); confirms absence of neurodegenerative pattern

Extended.timing: If diagnostic uncertainty for early Alzheimer disease vs FCD in patients 50-85 years
Extended.target: Amyloid-negative supports FCD diagnosis; amyloid-positive raises concern for AD pathology

Extended.timing: If seizure-related cognitive complaints or transient amnestic episodes

Rare/Specialized.timing: If amyloid PET unavailable and high diagnostic uncertainty
If sleep disorder suspected as primary contributor (obstructive sleep apnea)

Acute/Emergent (Cognitive Crisis Present.indication: Acute cognitive complaint presentation in ED; patient distress about memory loss

dosing.instructions: Use calm, validating language; "I can see how distressing these symptoms are"; avoid dismissive statements; do not say "there's nothing wrong"; provide clear plan for outpatient workup

Acute/Emergent (Cognitive Crisis Present.monitoring: Patient anxiety level; understanding of plan

Acute/Emergent (Cognitive Crisis Present.indication: Acute confusion or cognitive change in ED/inpatient setting; must differentiate FCD exacerbation from delirium

dosing.instructions: Complete metabolic workup; medication review; assess for infection, intoxication, metabolic derangement; CAM score for delirium; if negative for organic cause and consistent with known FCD pattern, reassure

Acute/Emergent (Cognitive Crisis Present.monitoring: Mental status; vital signs; CAM score

Acute/Emergent (Cognitive Crisis Present.item: Lorazepam (ONLY if severe panic/acute anxiety with cognitive symptoms)
Acute/Emergent (Cognitive Crisis Present.indication: Severe acute anxiety with functional cognitive decompensation; NOT for routine FCD

doseOptions.orderSentence: Lorazepam (ONLY if severe panic/acute anxiety with cognitive symptoms) 0.5 mg PO

dosing.instructions: 0.5-1 mg PO or IV x1 PRN for severe anxiety only; do NOT use routinely; avoid repeated dosing; transition to non-benzodiazepine anxiolytic
dosing.orderSentence: Lorazepam (ONLY if severe panic/acute anxiety with cognitive symptoms) 0.5 mg PO

Acute/Emergent (Cognitive Crisis Present.contraindications: Respiratory depression; acute alcohol intoxication; myasthenia gravis
Acute/Emergent (Cognitive Crisis Present.monitoring: Respiratory status; sedation level; do not continue beyond acute episode

Diagnosis Communication and Psychoeducat.indication: All FCD patients; the single most important therapeutic intervention

dosing.instructions: Explain FCD as a real condition where the brain's "filing system" works correctly but the "search function" is disrupted; memory is encoded but retrieval is inefficient due to attention/anxiety interference; show patient their NORMAL test results as evidence that memory hardware is intact; contrast with dementia pattern; validate symptoms; express confidence in diagnosis and treatability

Diagnosis Communication and Psychoeducat.monitoring: Patient understanding; acceptance; emotional response; therapeutic alliance

Diagnosis Communication and Psychoeducat.indication: All FCD patients; understanding the mechanism of cognitive symptoms

dosing.instructions: Teach the attention-memory model: anxiety and poor sleep hijack attentional resources needed for memory encoding and retrieval; demonstrate with divided attention tasks; explain that memory improves when attention improves; provide written materials and neurosymptoms.org/cognitive-symptoms

Diagnosis Communication and Psychoeducat.indication: Family members concerned about dementia; caregiver burden; family reinforcing illness behavior

dosing.instructions: Educate family that FCD is NOT dementia and will NOT progress to dementia; teach family to avoid "testing" the patient's memory (harmful); encourage normal activities and independence; reduce accommodation of avoidance behaviors

Diagnosis Communication and Psychoeducat.monitoring: Family understanding; reduction in accommodation behaviors

Psychological Treatment (Primary Treatme.indication: All FCD patients; addresses cognitive illness beliefs, attentional bias to errors, avoidance, catastrophizing

dosing.instructions: Weekly 50-min sessions; FCD-specific CBT targeting: (1) unhelpful illness beliefs ("I'm getting dementia"), (2) attentional monitoring of cognitive errors, (3) avoidance of cognitively demanding activities, (4) safety behaviors (excessive list-making, reliance on reminders); includes behavioral experiments and graded cognitive challenges

Psychological Treatment (Primary Treatme.contraindications: Active psychosis; severe cognitive impairment (true dementia)
Psychological Treatment (Primary Treatme.monitoring: Cognitive complaint severity (self-report); PHQ-9; GAD-7; functional measures; return to activities

Psychological Treatment (Primary Treatme.indication: FCD with prominent worry and rumination about cognitive symptoms; health anxiety

dosing.instructions: Weekly 50-min sessions; targets metacognitive beliefs ("worrying about my memory helps me catch problems"); reduces cognitive self-monitoring; attention training technique (ATT); detached mindfulness for intrusive thoughts about cognitive failure

Psychological Treatment (Primary Treatme.monitoring: Metacognitive beliefs questionnaire; worry frequency; cognitive complaint severity

Psychological Treatment (Primary Treatme.indication: FCD with avoidance of valued activities due to cognitive symptoms; fusion with thoughts about cognitive decline

dosing.instructions: Weekly 50-min sessions; cognitive defusion from "I'm losing my mind" thoughts; values-based engagement in activities despite cognitive concerns; mindfulness of cognitive experiences without judgment

Psychological Treatment (Primary Treatme.monitoring: Valued activity engagement; cognitive complaint severity; acceptance measures

Psychological Treatment (Primary Treatme.indication: FCD with comorbid depression; recurrent worry cycles about cognition

dosing.instructions: 8-week group (2 hours/week) plus home practice; adapted for FCD: mindful attention to present experience rather than monitoring for cognitive errors; body scan; sitting meditation; 3-minute breathing space

Psychological Treatment (Primary Treatme.monitoring: PHQ-9; GAD-7; cognitive complaint frequency; mindfulness practice adherence

Psychological Treatment (Primary Treatme.indication: All FCD patients; reduces isolation; normalizes experience; peer support

dosing.instructions: Structured group (6-10 patients) covering FCD education, attention-memory model, stress management, graded cognitive activity, relapse prevention

Psychological Treatment (Primary Treatme.monitoring: Attendance; patient satisfaction; cognitive complaint severity

Pharmacologic Management of Comorbiditie.indication: Comorbid depression (present in >60% FCD patients); generalized anxiety

dosing.instructions: Start 50 mg daily; titrate q2-4wk by 25-50 mg; max 200 mg/day; takes 4-6 weeks for full effect

Pharmacologic Management of Comorbiditie.monitoring: Suicidality (first 8 weeks); serotonin syndrome; QTc if risk factors; assess cognitive complaint trajectory at 8 weeks

Pharmacologic Management of Comorbiditie.indication: Comorbid depression and/or anxiety; better tolerated in elderly

dosing.instructions: Start 5 mg daily x 1 week in elderly; then 10 mg daily; max 20 mg/day (10 mg if >65 years)

Pharmacologic Management of Comorbiditie.monitoring: QTc if >65 years or cardiac risk; suicidality; hyponatremia in elderly

Pharmacologic Management of Comorbiditie.indication: Comorbid depression + chronic pain (fibromyalgia, chronic fatigue -- common FCD comorbidities)

dosing.instructions: Start 30 mg daily x 1 week; increase to 60 mg daily; max 120 mg/day

Pharmacologic Management of Comorbiditie.contraindications: Hepatic impairment; concurrent MAOIs; uncontrolled glaucoma
Pharmacologic Management of Comorbiditie.monitoring: BP; LFTs; serotonin syndrome; discontinuation syndrome (taper slowly)

Pharmacologic Management of Comorbiditie.indication: Comorbid depression + anxiety refractory to SSRI; somatic symptom burden

dosing.instructions: Start 37.5 mg daily x 1 week; titrate q1wk by 37.5 mg; target 75-150 mg/day; max 225 mg/day

Pharmacologic Management of Comorbiditie.monitoring: BP; HR; discontinuation syndrome (taper very slowly -- long taper schedule)

Pharmacologic Management of Comorbiditie.indication: Comorbid depression + insomnia + poor appetite (common in anxious FCD patients)

dosing.instructions: Start 7.5-15 mg qHS; may increase to 30 mg qHS; paradoxically more sedating at lower doses; max 45 mg/day

Pharmacologic Management of Comorbiditie.monitoring: Weight gain; sedation; lipid profile; CBC (rare agranulocytosis)

Pharmacologic Management of Comorbiditie.indication: Insomnia (common perpetuating factor in FCD; poor sleep worsens cognition)

dosing.instructions: Start 25-50 mg PO qHS; titrate q3-5d; max 100 mg qHS for insomnia

Pharmacologic Management of Comorbiditie.indication: Insomnia; circadian rhythm disruption contributing to daytime cognitive fog

dosing.instructions: 3-5 mg PO 30-60 min before desired bedtime; use immediate-release formulation; max 5 mg/day

Pharmacologic Management of Comorbiditie.indication: Acute situational anxiety; PRN anxiolytic without benzodiazepine risk

dosing.instructions: 25-50 mg PO q6-8h PRN anxiety; max 100 mg/dose

Pharmacologic Management of Comorbiditie.monitoring: QTc; sedation; anticholinergic effects (caution in elderly)

Pharmacologic Management of Comorbiditie.indication: Somatic anxiety symptoms (palpitations, tremor) contributing to cognitive performance anxiety

dosing.instructions: Start 10 mg PO BID; titrate q1wk; max 80 mg BID; helpful before cognitively demanding situations

Pharmacologic Management of Comorbiditie.contraindications: Asthma; AV block; bradycardia; decompensated CHF

Pharmacologic Management of Comorbiditie.indication: Generalized anxiety disorder comorbidity; alternative to benzodiazepines for chronic anxiety

dosing.instructions: Start 5 mg PO TID; titrate q2-3d by 5 mg/day; max 60 mg/day; takes 2-4 weeks for full effect

Pharmacologic Management of Comorbiditie.monitoring: Dizziness; headache; serotonin syndrome if combined with SSRI/SNRI

Cholinesterase Inhibitor Taper (If Inapp.indication: Patient with confirmed FCD who was inappropriately started on donepezil; discontinuation to avoid side effects and illness reinforcement

doseOptions.orderSentence: Gradual donepezil taper Per taper schedule PO

dosing.instructions: If on 10 mg, reduce to 5 mg x 2-4 weeks, then discontinue; reassure patient this medication was for a different condition; explain FCD does not require this treatment
dosing.orderSentence: Gradual donepezil taper Per taper schedule PO

Cholinesterase Inhibitor Taper (If Inapp.contraindications: True comorbid Alzheimer disease (confirm with biomarkers before discontinuing)
Cholinesterase Inhibitor Taper (If Inapp.monitoring: Cognitive complaint trajectory; reassurance; no withdrawal syndrome expected

Referrals & Consults.item: Neurology (cognitive-behavioral specialist if available) for FCD diagnosis confirmation, neuropsychological test interpretation, and structured diagnosis delivery
Neuropsychology for formal cognitive testing to differentiate FCD from neurodegenerative MCI/dementia and identify specific cognitive profile
Clinical psychology (CBT-trained) for cognitive-behavioral therapy targeting illness beliefs, attentional bias, and avoidance behaviors
Psychiatry for medication management of comorbid depression/anxiety if refractory to primary care treatment
Sleep medicine if suspected obstructive sleep apnea or primary sleep disorder contributing to daytime cognitive dysfunction
Occupational therapy for cognitive strategy training and return-to-work/school support
Social work for disability support, workplace accommodation, and psychosocial stressors contributing to FCD
Primary care follow-up for chronic disease management, medication reconciliation, and longitudinal cognitive monitoring
Pain management if chronic pain comorbidity (fibromyalgia, chronic headache) contributing to cognitive complaints
Peer support group for functional neurological disorders (FND Hope, FND Action) for normalization and shared experience

Patient Instructions.item: Your cognitive symptoms are REAL -- Functional Cognitive Disorder means your brain's "search engine" is working inefficiently, but your memory storage is intact (this is NOT dementia)
Visit www.neurosymptoms.org/cognitive-symptoms for reliable, expert-written information about functional cognitive symptoms
FCD does NOT progress to dementia -- your brain structure is healthy; cognitive efficiency improves with treatment of underlying anxiety, depression, and sleep problems

Stop monitoring your memory for errors -- constantly checking whether you remembered something correctly WORSENS cognitive performance by diverting attention (like a computer running too many background programs)
Reduce reliance on excessive compensatory strategies (constant list-making, asking others to confirm memories, avoiding new information) -- these safety behaviors maintain the problem
Prioritize sleep -- poor sleep is one of the strongest drivers of cognitive inefficiency; aim for 7-9 hours of consistent, quality sleep
Engage with recommended psychological therapy (CBT, MCT) -- these are the evidence-based treatments for FCD and have demonstrated improvement in studies
Limit internet searches about dementia -- health anxiety and "Dr. Google" reinforce catastrophic beliefs and worsen cognitive symptoms
Return to activities you have been avoiding due to cognitive concerns -- gradual re-engagement improves cognitive confidence and function
Return to ED for NEW symptoms clearly different from your usual cognitive complaints, such as sudden severe headache, sudden confusion with fever, one-sided weakness, or seizures

Lifestyle & Prevention.item: Regular aerobic exercise (30 min, 5x/week) to improve mood, sleep quality, and cognitive function through increased cerebral blood flow and neuroplasticity
Sleep hygiene optimization: consistent bed/wake times, avoid screens 1 hour before bed, limit caffeine after noon, dark/cool bedroom -- poor sleep is the #1 modifiable perpetuating factor for FCD
Stress management through mindfulness, breathing exercises, progressive muscle relaxation, or yoga -- chronic stress impairs attentional resources needed for memory
Limit alcohol intake (alcohol directly impairs cognitive function and sleep architecture, worsening FCD symptoms)
Maintain social engagement and intellectually stimulating activities -- isolation and cognitive inactivity worsen subjective cognitive complaints
Pacing activities to avoid cognitive overload -- schedule demanding tasks during peak alertness (typically morning); take breaks to prevent attention fatigue
Balanced diet with emphasis on Mediterranean-style eating pattern for brain health (fruits, vegetables, whole grains, omega-3 fatty acids)
Reduce multitasking -- single-task focus improves cognitive performance; multitasking divides attention and increases subjective memory failures

differential.features: Progressive episodic memory loss with encoding failure; hippocampal atrophy; abnormal biomarkers; insidious onset over years; loss of recent memories with preservation of remote
differential.tests: Neuropsychological testing (encoding deficit with poor cuing); MRI (hippocampal atrophy); amyloid PET or CSF biomarkers (abnormal amyloid/tau); FDG-PET (temporoparietal hypometabolism)

differential.features: Objective memory impairment (1-1.5 SD below norms) with preserved daily function; gradual progression; may convert to dementia
differential.tests: Neuropsychological testing (objective deficit on delayed recall); serial testing (progressive decline); biomarkers if available

differential.features: Personality change; disinhibition; apathy; executive dysfunction; relatively preserved memory; frontal atrophy
differential.tests: Neuropsychological testing (executive > memory deficit); MRI (frontal/temporal atrophy); FDG-PET (frontal hypometabolism)

differential.features: Visual hallucinations; fluctuating cognition; parkinsonism; REM sleep behavior disorder; visuospatial deficits
differential.tests: DaTscan (abnormal); polysomnography (RBD); neuropsychological testing (visuospatial + attention > memory); MRI (less atrophy than AD)

differential.features: Prominent mood symptoms preceding cognitive complaints; effort-related poor performance; improves with antidepressant treatment; "I don't know" responses
differential.tests: PHQ-9; neuropsychological testing (effort-dependent, inconsistent performance); treatment response to antidepressants

differential.features: Prominent anxiety; attentional deficits secondary to worry; catastrophizing about normal memory lapses; hypervigilance to cognitive errors
differential.tests: GAD-7; neuropsychological testing (attention/processing speed deficits with intact memory encoding); treatment response

differential.features: Excessive daytime sleepiness; snoring; witnessed apneas; morning headaches; cognitive fog improves after CPAP treatment
differential.tests: Polysomnography (AHI); CPAP trial with cognitive reassessment

differential.features: Temporal correlation with medication initiation; anticholinergic burden; benzodiazepines; opioids; anticonvulsants
differential.tests: Medication review (Beers criteria, anticholinergic burden score); trial medication reduction; cognitive reassessment

differential.features: Prominent fatigue and "brain fog"; widespread pain; sleep disruption; overlaps significantly with FCD
differential.tests: Clinical criteria for CFS/fibromyalgia; neuropsychological testing shows attention/processing speed deficits

differential.features: Mild subjective cognitive slowing; tip-of-the-tongue phenomena; normal neuropsychological performance; not functionally impairing
differential.tests: Age-adjusted neuropsychological norms (performance within normal range); stable over time

differential.features: Subacute onset; seizures; psychiatric symptoms; movement disorder; MRI/EEG abnormalities
differential.tests: Autoimmune encephalitis antibody panel (serum and CSF); MRI; EEG

differential.features: Acute onset; fluctuating attention; altered consciousness; identifiable medical cause
differential.tests: CAM score; metabolic workup; medication review; resolves with treatment of underlying cause

monitoring.item: Cognitive complaint severity (self-report visual analog scale or Cognitive Failures Questionnaire)
monitoring.action: Reassess treatment plan; address perpetuating factors; consider alternative psychological therapy modality
Adjust antidepressant; intensify psychological treatment; psychiatric referral if refractory
Adjust anxiolytic therapy; psychological treatment intensification
If declining: repeat neuropsychological testing to exclude emerging neurodegenerative process

monitoring.item: Sleep quality (Pittsburgh Sleep Quality Index or Insomnia Severity Index)
monitoring.action: Sleep hygiene review; consider pharmacologic sleep aid; sleep medicine referral

monitoring.frequency: Baseline; repeat at 12-18 months if diagnostic uncertainty
monitoring.action: If progressive decline on serial formal testing: reconsider diagnosis; biomarker workup for neurodegeneration
Address avoidance behaviors; occupational therapy; graded activity plan
Explore barriers; motivational interviewing; adjust treatment modality
Dose adjustment; medication switch; reassess need

monitoring.item: Safety behaviors and avoidance (self-monitoring, list dependence, activity avoidance)
monitoring.action: Behavioral activation; CBT focus on safety behavior reduction

disposition.criteria: Acute organic cause excluded; FCD suspected or confirmed; patient reassured; outpatient neurology/neuropsychology referral arranged; return precautions provided; primary care follow-up scheduled

Diagnostic uncertainty requiring expedited workup (subacute onset raising concern for autoimmune encephalitis or rapidly progressive dementia); acute psychiatric comorbidity (suicidality, severe depression); unable to care for self due to functional disability
Generally NOT indicated for FCD; consider only if: iatrogenic complications (e.g., medication toxicity); concurrent acute medical condition requiring ICU care
Neuropsychology not available locally; specialized FND/FCD clinic referral; inpatient psychiatric care if severe comorbid psychiatric illness

ALL patients: neurology follow-up within 2-4 weeks for diagnosis delivery and education; neuropsychological testing within 1-3 months; psychology referral (CBT) within 1 month; PCP for comorbidity management

Acute cognitive change DIFFERENT from baseline FCD pattern (new confusion, fever, focal deficits -- evaluate for new organic pathology); acute psychiatric emergency; failure of outpatient treatment with severe functional decline
